10.1: They studied their own rulings and those of Beit Shammai - When Beit Shammai would bring proof to their rulings from the Torah and Beit Hillel would bring proof from another verse, and Beit Hillel would expound the verse of Beit Shammai to show its relevance, and it was not light in their eyes, as they studied in Tractate Berakhot (Berakhot 10b), "Beit Shammai say, In the morning, every man should lean and read [Kiryat Shema'] and in the morning he should stand as it says, (Devarim 6:7) 'When you lie down and when you arise'; and Beit Hillel say, Every man should read as he is, as it says, (Ibid.) 'When you are on the way'. If so, what does it say, 'When you lie down and when you arise'? - [Recite] at the time that people normally lie down and at the time that people normally arise [i.e., in the evening and in the morning]."
10.2: They mention the actions of Beth Shammai before theirs - As they first said in the story that the "elders of Beth Shammai went" and subsequently, the "elders of Beth Hillel".

0.0: Or perhaps he [Rav Chisda] is asking whether the law is like Rabbi Eliezer, who said in our Mishna (ahead on 52b) that someone he went outside the Shabbos boundary 2 hand-breadths [or less], can go back inside [the boundary].

2.0: Also it is precisely stated: that it is a case where there were not enough people [to form a complete enclosure extending all the way back to the Shabbos boundary]...
2.1: Because he said to him: Rav Nachman [said] to make for him [Rav Nechamia] a wall of people, and [then] he will "enter".  Why would he need to add the word "enter" [if the wall already extended his path inside the boundary]?  Rather, what it means to say is: he [Rav Chisda] should make an enclosure (until) 2 hand-breadths [of the boundary], and then he [Rav Nechemia] would walk in on his own [passing through a 2 hand-breadth space outside the boundary] with no enclosure.

3.0: It's wall fell -- of a Sukkah
3.1: And he should not stand up a bed frame: That he has in the Sukkah [to stand] in place of the gap [in the wall]. And even though it does not look like a [prohibited] act of building [on Yom Tov] -- because it appear as if he is [simply] intending to clear out space in the Sukkah -- even so, it is prohibited.  And this presents a difficulty to [Rav Nachman's instruction] which allows making a wall of people on Shabbos.

4.0: In order that he can eat, drink and sleep:  The main Mitzva of Sukkah is [performed through] these 3 things.
4.1: And he can stand up a bed frame: Therefore we see that it is permitted [to set up something to create a wall on Shabbos].  And the Gemara is going to investigate the contradiction between these two Baraitot.

5.0: And if [it is] not [attached and hanging on the building], one may not use it to shutter [the window], because it is similar [to the prohibited act of] building -- since he is increasing the enclosure of the room.  And even though it is only temporary -- because he will go back and open it up again.

6.0: But has it not been stated - that even the Rabbis only permitted to add [to an existing structure], for example,  by shuttering a window, which is merely adding. But the Baraisa permits to make a wall from scratch.

7.0: Rabbi Meir invalidates - it is explained in Tractate Sukkah -- lest the animal runs away [which is Rabbi Meir's reason for invalidating using an animal as a Sukkah wall].

8.0: Because he did not do anything - since  [the wall] does not complete a Sukkah -- even though it is making a enclosure [Ohel] -- it is permitted.  He [Rabbi Meir] is holding that we do make temporary enclosures [on Shabbat] -- since he is not completing a Sukkah it is only a temporary enclosure -- and is permitted.
8.1: But still, there is a lot to ask on [this explanation], because the the Baraisa is stating "in order that he can eat, drink, and sleep".  We see from this that indeed this wall is coming to complete the Sukkah.  The Gemara will continue to question this explanation until it is [eventually] removed from the [final] explanation.

10.0: Say that you hear from Rabbi Meir - that he invalidates
10.1: An animal - because [of the reason] lest it will run away
10.2: A person - who has the awareness to stand [in place], or utensils, which do not move from their place -- have you heard him teach that?  And this Tanna [in the second Baraisa] is stating that a person and utensils [are allowed, even though they may also be valid Sukkah walls], saying: one makes his friend into a wall, and stands up the bed frame.
